question: Consider events $A$ and $B$ with both $P(A)>0$ and $P(B)>0$. Which of the following statements are true?

answers.answer: $$P(A|B) \ge P(A)$$ (I.e., given some information, the probability increases or remains the same.)
$$P(A|B) \le P(A)$$ (I.e., given some information, the probability decreases or remains the same.)
$$P(A|B) = P(A)$$ (Conditional information does not change the probability of an event.)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. You should have already seen multiple examples to disprove this in Chapter 5. If you believed this answer was correct when you chose it, you should review Chapter 5 from the beginning.

answers.answer: $P(A|B)$ may be less than, equal to, or greater than $P(A)$, depending on the information given.
